page.title: 14FARMING
page.content: Another farm in the block is 300 acres. In 1985, 177 acres were under wheat, 42 under barley, 42 under oil-seed rape, and 16 were under peas for freezing. The farm also had one and a half acres of woodland, planted for foxes and pheasants in the late 18th century. The farm is worked by the farm owner, with occasional help from his son, and one other man at harvest. This means a large investment in machinery, and extensive use of chemical pest- and herbicides. This farm also has a grain drier, built in 1961. Some heifers and calves are kept. They graze outside in the summer, and are sold as stores for fattening in the autumn. In the past, store-cattle have been bought in, kept in the crew-yard, and fed on hay and rolled barley until weight and market prices were right.
